title: The First Pattern
description: Learn to create your first Kente pattern with Kwaku Ananse
learningObjectives: Learn about the cultural significance of patterns

steps.title: The Beginning
steps.content: Kwaku Ananse, the clever spider of Ghanaian folklore, has taken on a new role in the digital age. As a master weaver and coding expert, he has decided to teach you the art of Kente weaving through code.

steps.title: The Cultural Significance
steps.content: After completing the tutorial, Ananse explains the deeper meaning behind the Dame-Dame pattern. "This checkerboard pattern represents duality in Akan philosophy - the balance between opposites that creates harmony in life."

culturalContext.title: Dame-Dame Pattern
culturalContext.description: The Dame-Dame (checker) pattern represents duality in Akan philosophy. It symbolizes the balance between opposites - like light and dark, joy and sorrow, the seen and unseen. It is one of the first patterns taught to young weavers in Ghana.

steps.speaker: Kwaku

steps.title: Your First Challenge
steps.content: "Now it's time to put what you've learned into practice," Ananse says. "Create a Dame-Dame pattern using the blocks we've discussed. Remember to think about the colors you choose - they each have their own meaning in Kente tradition."
